conclusion: To determine whether Car A is ahead of or behind Car B at t = 10 seconds, we need to analyze the areas under their respective velocity-time (v-t) graphs up to t = 10 seconds.
The area under the v-t graph gives the distance traveled by each car.
Car A has a constant velocity of 40 m/s from t = 0 to t = 30 seconds.
Car B accelerates linearly from t = 0 to t = 20 seconds and then maintains a constant velocity until t = 30 seconds.

premise: Car A's velocity is constant at 40 m/s.
conclusion: Distance traveled by Car A from t = 0 to t = 10 seconds: d_A = v_A × t = 40 m/s × 10 s = 400 m

premise: From t = 0 to t = 10 seconds, Car B accelerates linearly.
conclusion: To find the acceleration a: a = Δv/Δt = 40 m/s / 10 s = 4 m/s²
The distance traveled by Car B during this period using the equation of motion: d_B = 1/2 a t² = 1/2 × 4 m/s² × (10 s)² = 200 m

premise: Distance traveled by Car A: 400 m. Distance traveled by Car B: 200 m.
conclusion: Car A is ahead of Car B by 400 m - 200 m = 200 m.

premise: Since the two cars are side by side at t=30 s.
conclusion: Therefore, the two cars are also side by side at t=10 s.
